column2: Standardized score from 12-item Relational Mobility Scale (1–6 Likert items). Higher values = greater perceived relational mobility.
Standardized score from 5-item Responsibilism Scale (1–7 Likert items). Higher values = greater reported responsiblism.
Standardized score from 6-item Tightness-Looseness Scale (1–6 Likert items). Higher values = greater tightness.
Percentage of people answering "Yes" to the question "Is religion an important part of your daily life?"
Gross Domestic Product (GDP) representing the average  the total market value of all final goods and services produced within a country from 2011-2020.
A measure of the frequency with which individuals or populations change their place of residence. Higher values = greater residential mobility.
A measure of the extent to which less powerful members of a society accept and expect that power is distributed unequally. Higher values = strong hierarchies, acceptance of authority.
A measure of the degree to which people are integrated into groups. Higher values = more individualistic.
A measure of the degree to which people prioritize assertiveness, competition, and material success over quality of life, relationships, and caring. Higher values = higher motivation.
A measure of the extent to which members of a culture feel threatened by ambiguous or unknown situations. Higher values = preference for stability.
A measure of the degree to which societies embrace future-oriented values like perseverance and thrift, versus short-term traditions. Higher values = preference for long-term values.
A measure of the extent to which societies allow relatively free gratification of basic human desires related to enjoying life and having fun.. Higher values = higher indulgence.
If the country was sampled in the study
